In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This technical assistance (TA) is to foster more effective infrastructure development in 
the West Asia developing member countries (DMCs) by improving their land acquisition and 
resettlement (LAR) performance. This will be accomplished by (i) providing a capacity building 
program  to  increase  the  understanding  of  governments  and  nongovernment  organizations 
(NGOs) of the LAR aspects of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009) and LAR improvements needed in each DMC; (ii) promoting country ownership of sound 
LAR; (iii) narrowing gaps between local practice and ADB policy; and (iv) developing procedures 
and technical tools to prepare and execute better resettlement plans. The TA is consistent with 
the  2009  ADB  Safeguard  Policy  Statement1 and  the  2006  special  evaluation  study  of  the 
Independent  Evaluation  Department 2 and  supports  Strategy  2020 3 and  the  2005  Paris 
Declaration agenda.4  
 
2.  ADB has financed similar TA projects5 but, except for Pakistan, they never involved 
DMCs in the region covered by ADB’s Central and West Asia Department (CWRD). Moreover, 
these  efforts  had  mixed  results  in  improving  LAR  performance  as  they  provided  only 
assessments,  recommendations,  or  draft  country  policies  or  policy  agendas.  This  TA 
incorporates  lessons  from  these  past  efforts,  but  focuses  primarily  on  LAR  improvements 
obtainable  under  existing  laws,  such  as  solving  administrative  bottlenecks,  improving 
coordination,  and  providing  technical  know-how.  Discussions  with  executing  agencies, 
consultants,  and  NGOs  during  project  missions  confirm  the  TA's  relevance  and  the 
governments’ support for the initiative. Specific agreements with each government on their 
participation in the TA programs will be obtained during TA inception. The TA design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Of  the  factors  involved  in  infrastructure  development,  LAR  is  a  main  cause  of 
development  partner–client  disagreements,  delays,  and  stakeholder  complaints.  This  is 
especially the case in Central and West Asia where, since CWRD was established, infrastructure 
projects with intensive LAR have constantly increased, but LAR capacity remains weak. Most 
DMCs in the region are unfamiliar with ADB policy. They maintain LAR practices that are 
obsolete or imperfectly recognize private property. They also lack institutional, administrative, or 
technical  tools  to  execute  LAR  effectively  and  based  on  sound  international  standards. 
Therefore, maximizing the benefits of new infrastructure in the region requires overhauling local 
LAR practices. The need is urgent and requires resources and dedicated efforts.7  
                                                 
1  ADB. 2009. Safeguards Policy Statement. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2006. Special Evaluation Study on Involuntary Resettlement Safeguards, Manila. 
3  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. Manila. 
4   Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness. February 28–2 March 2005. 
5  ADB. 1998. Technical Assistance for the Review of Resettlement Policies and Experiences with Involuntary 
Resettlement Projects. Manila (TA 5781-REG); ADB. 2000. Technical Assistance for National Resettlement Policy 
Enhancement and Capacity Building. Manila. (TA 5935-REG); ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance for Capacity 
Building for Resettlement Risk Management. Manila. (TA 6091-REG). 
6  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 23 October 2009. 
7  The  TA  consultants  will  prepare  comprehensive  assessments  and  sustained  capacity  building  programs 
addressing country and cross-sector issues. This cannot be done by project preparatory TA or supervision 
consultants who focus on project-specific tasks and encounter great difficulties in their work exactly because the 
LAR-enabling environment to be delivered by the TA is missing.

2   
4.  One area where LAR complicates the preparation and implementation of projects is legal. 
Most DMCs have laws that do not support the ADB policy's compensation or rehabilitation 
standards. These differences slow loan processing and mar negotiations. Moreover, even if 
agreements  are  clear  in  loan  covenants,  they  do  not  guarantee  that  LAR  is  implemented 
according to ADB standards. Local governments, which usually are responsible for LAR, do not 
sign loan agreements nor understand ADB policy and are thus unable to implement it or are 
afraid they will break the law if they do so. To overcome these obstacles, ADB may engage in 
legal reform to bring national laws in line with ADB policy. Efforts and dialogue in this direction 
are surely necessary, but will provide results only in the long term. Legal reform is complex and 
depends on independent parliamentary action or political interests, and establishing strong 
country systems and country ownership of improved LAR dynamics requires gradual change.  
 
5.  In parallel with these long-term efforts, quicker LAR improvement may be pursued within 
existing country systems by addressing other causes of poor LAR: for instance, how current 
laws are implemented or the lack of conducive environments for law implementation. These 
efforts may target a generalized DMC rigidity to creatively handle existing laws or regulations. In 
this  sense,  proper  legal  advice  can  facilitate  policy  negotiations  by  convincing  DMCs  that 
existing laws can actually support ADB policy provisions that are not in the laws but are only of 
a technical nature.8 Better LAR can also be sought by establishing streamlined procedures, 
proper planning mechanisms, or more effective interagency coordination. Often poor LAR rests 
on its relegation as an external or secondary factor in project development; on the priority given 
to civil works schedules over LAR schedules; on the fact that executing agencies have no LAR 
offices or, if they do, they are weakly staffed and trained; and on the dependency of LAR tasks 
on  many  separate  and  uncoordinated  participants.9 In  these  circumstances,  LAR  may  be 
unsystematic, slowly executed, or a source of complaints. To improve this situation, agreement 
must be reached with the DMC on (i) developing templates synchronizing LAR, civil works, and 
disbursement  schedules;  (ii)  preparing  implementation-ready  resettlement  plans  before 
construction contracts are binding; and (iii) ensuring that all affected parties are compensated 
before civil works begin. Equally important is to set up LAR units within the executing agencies 
with clear mandates and capacity; establish agreed mechanisms ensuring coordination; and 
develop operating modalities leading to the involvement of all concerned parties in each project 
phase, including preparation, implementation, and negotiations with development partners.  
 
6.  Another source of poor LAR practice is the inadequacy of technical tools or know-how. 
LAR preparation is slowed by inaccurate maps, corrections to badly executed surveys, or weak 
public  participation  skills.  Lack  of  sound  asset  valuation  methods  may  limit  compensation 
options and cause lengthy discussions or complaints before a resettlement plan is acceptable. 
Finally,  poor  resettlement  plan  conceptualization  may  require  repeated  rewritings  delaying 
project or contract approval. These difficulties can be solved by training or technical innovation 
carried out in formal sessions and ad hoc studies. To be truly successful and leave durable 
results, such initiatives are to be supported by sustained coaching and assistance during the 
application of new skills and techniques in actual project work. 
                                                 
8  An example is common resistance of borrowers to prepare resettlement plans based on the argument that they are 
not mandated by national laws. These arguments may be dispelled by showing that all LAR laws require proper 
impact assessments and that a resettlement plan is only a more comprehensive and systematic instrument to meet 
the same requirement. Another example is the claim in some countries that legally land compensation in cash is 
impossible when actually the law is silent on this matter and the problem depends on the lack of accepted land 
valuation methodologies, which in itself is a technical issue.    
9  Executing agencies tend to focus on the financial and civil works aspects of a project, but leave direct responsibility 
for LAR tasks (for which they are often unprepared) to consultants or to national land acquisition agencies and local 
governments.  In  turn  these  latter  institutions  are  not  involved  in  the  negotiations  with  ADB  nor  know  the 
requirements of ADB policy.

3
 
7.  Finally, LAR is a most common source of reputational risks. Complaints from affected 
people may involve weak consultation and information, inadequacy of compensation rates or 
delivery, and divergences between LAR implementation and resettlement plan stipulations. 
Also, complaints may be sometimes unjustified, be easily solved, or be so problematic that they 
bring a project to a standstill. Yet, regardless of their gravity, complaints always complicate and 
slow  project  implementation,  cause  costs,  and  erode  citizen  confidence  in  institutions.  To 
improve this, executing agencies must fully consult with the affected people, properly disclose 
project documents, and when necessary take action to correct mistakes. To simplify and reduce 
delays in resolving complaints, the executing agencies and NGOs lodging the complaints must 
be well prepared to relate to each other. This requires that executing agencies are properly 
trained in grievance handling, public participation, and public relations; and NGOs are trained on 
how to raise issues in such a way as to elicit prompt response from the executing agencies 
through clear descriptions and substantiation of the issues at stake.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA's impact will be more effective infrastructure development in the Central and 
West Asia DMCs. Its outcome will be improved LAR practices in the DMCs through greater 
understanding  of  the  ADB  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy  and  ownership  of  sound  LAR 
practices, enhanced LAR procedures and agency coordination and capacity; simpler project 
preparation and implementation dynamics, more timely disbursement, and reduced reputational 
risks. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  Output  1.  Country-specific  assessment  of  LAR  practice  and  action  plan  for 
capacity building. In each participating DMC, the TA will provide (i) greater awareness of the 
differences between ADB policy and local LAR needs and regulation; (ii) understanding of local 
LAR  practice  and  related  institutional  or  technical  factors  affecting  LAR  effectiveness  or 
compliance with ADB policy; and (iii) agreement on capacity building needs to improve LAR. 
This will be obtained through a country assessment study, and an institutional and technical 
capacity building plan. 
 
10.  Output  2.  Country-specific  alignment  of  policy  and  enhancement  of  LAR 
administration  and  procedures.  In  each  participating  DMC,  the  TA  will  lead  to  tangible 
advancements  in  policy  alignment  and  LAR  institutional  capacity.  The  output  will  result  in 
(i) enhancement of LAR mechanisms not requiring legal reform (procedures, implementing rules, 
interagency modalities of action); (ii) preparation of an agenda for changes requiring new or 
amended  laws  and  bring  each  DMC  to  the  position  to  borrow  ADB  funds  for  LAR;  and  
(iii) improvement in DMC–NGO partnerships and aid coordination. This output will require (i) the 
establishment of a LAR focal group in each DMC, (ii) periodic consultation with the focal group, 
(iii) workshops, and (iv) preparation of templates for modified practices and procedures agreed 
upon by executing agencies or other government agencies.  
 
11.  Output 3. Country-specific improvement of technical instruments for LAR. The 
technical capacity building program will provide each DMC with greater capacity for improved 
resettlement plan planning, faster implementation, surveys, and asset valuation; and mainstreamed 
mechanisms for stakeholder consultation and complaints handling. The output will include (i) a

4   
short-term  training  program  for  national  and  local  land  administration  agencies,  executing 
agencies, and NGOs to be carried out through formal training sessions, case studies, field visits, 
and  workshops;  (ii)  a  medium-term  coaching  and  training  on-the-job  program  involving 
protracted assistance to executing agencies of ADB projects during project preparation and 
implementation; (iii) preparation of terms of reference for the establishment of capable LAR 
teams in land administration agencies and/or selected executing agencies; and (iv) training of 
national consultants and establishment of a roster of capable national specialists.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $5,000,000 equivalent to be fully provided on a 
grant basis from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV).10 The governments will 
provide focal group members' salaries and cover other costs in kind. Detailed cost estimates 
and the financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  All countries in the CWRD region will be invited to participate in the TA, but the extent 
and specifics of activities may vary from country to country based on local needs. ADB will be 
the executing agency. Country support will be provided by the resident missions, the regional 
office  in  Almaty,  and  the  liaison  office  in  Ashgabat.  In  each  country,  a  focal  group  with 
representatives of land administration and line agencies, selected local governments, NGOs, 
and other development partners will help with TA activities including ensuring government 
feedback and facilitation of government decision-making processes; cross-departmental liaison; 
and assistance in planning meetings, workshops, and training. No TA activity will commence in 
any participating DMC until the DMC provides a no-objection letter. 
 
14.  The TA will last 48 months (February 2010 to February 2014), including (i) a 6-month 
inception period to determine DMC participation and hire the consultants; (ii) 36 months of 
actual TA delivery; and (iii) 6 months to close the TA. The ADB  project team leader will 
supervise the TA with the assistance, for Pakistan, of the ADB social safeguards team at the 
Pakistan Resident Mission. Overall TA coordination and field activities will be assigned to 
consultants engaged on an individual basis in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time).11 Overall coordination will be carried out by 
one  international  TA  coordinator  and  one  national  TA  administrator  located  at  ADB 
headquarters. Field activities will be carried out by four subregional teams, of which two will 
cover one country each (Pakistan and Afghanistan) and two will cover a country-grouping:  
(i) Central Asia cluster: Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan, 
and (ii) Caucasus cluster: Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia. The subregional teams will be 
based at resident missions or relevant regional or liaison offices. Each subregional team will 
include  one  international  specialist  and  team  leader  (who,  for  country-groupings,  may  be 
assisted by other international specialists as needed) plus one national specialist for each 
country. National experts on land law, asset valuation, land mapping, or other topics emerging 
as relevant during TA implementation may be hired in each country during TA implementation.  
                                                 
10  Cofinancing options were explored but no other funds for social development or safeguards were found. 
11  Consultants' engagement under a firm or through an indefinite delivery contract format was considered. However to 
limit costs; overcome the lack of firms specialized in resettlement; and fit TA activities which are country-specific 
and integrated in a process entailing assessment, planning, and implementation tasks, individual consultants will 
be engaged. To manage the complex handling of activities involving so many DMCs, a strong TA coordination 
team will be established at ADB headquarters.

5
 
15.  The international TA coordinator will work intermittently for 24 person-months and the 
national TA administrator intermittently for 36 person-months. The international specialists for 
the subregional teams will work intermittently for 7 person-months in each country; except for 
Pakistan, where they will work for 11 person-months, and Turkmenistan, where they will work 
for 2 person-months (total 69 months). The national specialists will be hired on a continuous 
basis for 36 person-months in each country except for Turkmenistan where they will work only 6 
person-months (total 330 person-months). International and national specialists will be located 
at ADB resident missions, and regional or liaison offices. The outline terms of reference for 
consultants are included in Appendix 3. 
 
16.  TA implementation will be divided into three phases: (i) phase 1, lasting up to 6 months 
for each country, will deliver the country study and capacity building action plan; (ii) phase 2 will 
be  carried  out  in  each  country  except  (at  least  initially)  Turkmenistan,  and  will  last  up  to  
24 months to implement the institutional and technical capacity building programs; and (iii) 
phase  3,  entailing  on-the-job  assistance  to  executing  agencies,  will  also  initially  exclude 
Turkmenistan and will start in parallel with phase 2, but will not be contingent on the success of 
phase 1 and will continue until the end of TA activities. The international specialists will directly 
participate in phases 1 and 2. Phase 3 will be carried out by the national specialists. At TA 
completion, the team leaders will carry out a 15-day mission for each country and/or country 
grouping  under  his/her  supervision  to  conduct  an  evaluation  of  the  TA  with  the  national 
consultant. 
 
17.  The TA will generate several knowledge products to be disseminated among executing 
agencies and civil society organizations through workshops, training manuals, and TA country 
reports. 
 
18.  The TA will require thorough monitoring. Where possible, the TA will make use of project 
performance reports and quarterly implementation reports of projects with LAR implemented in 
the TA countries. For indicators that are not included in standard ADB reporting documents, the 
TA will make use of a TA performance monitoring system to be designed by the international TA 
coordinator during the inception phase. The monitoring data will be filled in ad hoc forms by the 
national consultants or by project officers quarterly. The international TA coordinator will be 
responsible for preparing quarterly reports based on this monitoring data. At the end of the TA, 
the international and national consultants will prepare a TA country evaluation report. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
19.   The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  the  provision  of  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $5,000,000 on a grant basis for Mainstreaming Land 
Acquisition and Resettlement Safeguards in the Central and West Asia Region.

10    Appendix 4 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Implementation Arrangements, Responsibilities, Work Modality, and Time Frame 
 
1.  Overall technical assistance (TA) tasks will be supervised by the TA team leader with 
special inputs for Pakistan from the social safeguards team at the Pakistan Resident Mission 
and with the assistance of the international TA coordinator hired intermittently for 24 person-
months and a national TA administrator hired for 36 person-months, both located at Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) headquarters.  
 
2.  In-country activities will be led by four international specialists each acting as team 
leader of a subregional team in specific countries, i.e., Afghanistan and Pakistan, or county 
groupings: (i) Central Asia cluster: Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and 
Uzbekistan; and (ii) Caucasus cluster: Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia. To speed up TA 
activities in the two country groupings, the team leader may be assisted by other international 
specialists  working  in  specific  countries.  The  team  leader  will  be  joined  by  10  national 
specialists, one for each country. The international consultants (including team leaders and, 
when needed, additional international specialists) will be hired on an intermittent basis for a total 
of 7 person-months for each country, except for Pakistan where they will be engaged for 11 
person-months  and  Turkmenistan  2  person-months  (total  69  person-months).  The  national 
specialists will be hired for 36 person-months in each country except for Turkmenistan (6 
person-months) (total 330 person-months). Appendix 3 provides the distribution of consultants 
by category, location, and person-months. 
 
3.  Actual TA activities in each country will be provided over 36 months in three phases:  
(i)  Phase 1, lasting up to 6 months from the start of activities in each country, will 
involve  the  team  leader  (and  needed  international  specialists)  and  national 
specialist, and deliver a land acquisition and resettlement (LAR) country study 
and/or assessment and prepare an institutional and technical capacity building 
program.  
(ii)  Phase 2, to be triggered by the successful completion of phase 1, will last up to 
24  months  after  the  end  of  phase  1  in  each  country  (initially  excluding 
Turkmenistan). It will involve a team leader (and needed international specialists) 
and national specialist, and entail implementation of institutional and technical 
capacity building programs, except for on-the-job coaching of executing agencies. 
(iii)  Phase 3 devoted to medium-term on-the-job coaching will last 30 months and will 
start  in  parallel  with  phase  2  but  will  not  be  contingent  on  the  successful 
completion of phase 1. It will involve the team leader (and needed international 
specialists) and national specialist only until phase 2 is finished. After that, the 
tasks will be continued by the national specialist alone until the last month of the 
TA when the team leader will carry out a 0.5 person-month mission for each 
country  to  evaluate  the  TA  with  the  national  specialist.  If  phase  1  is  not 
completed  within  the  planned  period,  phase  3  will  continue  to  pursue  the 
conclusion of phase 1 tasks so as to start phase 2 tasks.  
 
4.  The  international  TA  coordinator  will  assist  the  project  team  leader  and  the  social 
safeguards team at the Pakistan Resident Mission by coordinating with the team leaders, 
advising on country tasks, and ensuring proper task scheduling. The coordinator will evaluate 
TA outputs and provide recommendations on the documents prepared by the subregional teams

Appendix 4  11
at the end of phases 1 and 2, and, if necessary, participate in discussions with the governments. 
Finally, the coordinator will prepare a TA monitoring system, participate in the final evaluation of 
the TA, and conduct review missions at the beginning and end of each TA phase and at the end 
of the TA. The coordinator will have at least 10 years of experience in project management and 
will be familiar with practices of multilateral financial institutions; experience with LAR-related 
work will be preferred. He or she will hold at least a masters degree in social sciences, land 
management,  project  planning  and/or  administration,  or  other  related  disciplines.  Work 
experience in the country and/or countries assigned is desirable.  
  
5.  The national TA administrator will be based at ADB headquarters. He or she will assist 
TA implementation by processing and updating internal ADB documents, carrying out financial 
and logistic administration tasks, and ensuring interdepartmental coordination of TA tasks within 
ADB.  The  administrator  will  have  thorough  knowledge  of  ADB  procedures,  demonstrated 
experience in project administration, and good writing skills. 
  
6.  The team leaders are expected to carry out five missions in the assigned countries, at 
the beginning and end of each phase to launch the activities of each new phase and conclude 
the activities of previous phases (the mission for the end of phase 2 will overlap with the first 
mission for phase 3). For the two country groupings additional missions may be carried by other 
international specialists as needed. The team leaders will work under the supervision of the TA 
team  leader1 and  international  specialist,  and  will  work  in  close  consultation  with  resident 
missions and focal agencies to plan TA activities in each assigned country. These tasks will 
include leading TA execution; train and/or supervise national specialists; and write action plans, 
reports,  and  other  documents  with  the  assistance  of  the  national specialists. The  national 
specialist will carry out TA tasks under the supervision of the TA team leader and resident 
mission, and with assistance, at a distance, of the international specialist. The national specialist 
will  also  carry  out  alone  most  of  the  tasks  under  the  medium-term  coaching  program  for 
executing agencies.  
 
7.  The team leaders will have at least 10 years of experience in LAR-related work and the 
international specialists 5 years; they will be familiar with practices of multilateral financial 
institutions and hold at least a masters degree in social sciences, land management project 
planning and/or administration, or other related disciplines. Work experience in the country 
and/or countries of assignment would be preferable. The national specialists will be fluent in 
spoken and written English; and have at least 4 years experience in social development, LAR, 
safeguard  policies,  land  management  and/or  administration;  and  an  appropriate  university 
degree related to social or environmental sciences, safeguards management, land management, 
or other related disciplines. 
 
B.  Tasks Assigned 
 
8.  Output 1: Country assessment of LAR mechanisms, effectiveness, and capacity 
building  needs  (international:  20  person-months;  national:  60  person-months).  In  each 
participating developing member country (DMC) the activities for this output will include the 
following:  
 
(i)  Review all LAR laws, rules, and regulations leading the operation of the land 
administration agency, main agencies, and local governments. 
                                                 
1  The TA team leader is the senior social development specialist at the social safeguards team in ADB’s Country 
Coordination and Regional Cooperation Division, Central and West Asia Department.

12    Appendix 4 
(ii)  Assess the country land administration system, including status and availability of 
land records and cadastral maps; official types of land tenure; procedures for 
registration and valuation of land and other assets; and degree to which law and 
regulation  are  systematically  applied  nationally  and  in  different  parts  of  the 
country. 
(iii)  Carry out an analytic study (involving field visits) of LAR practice for a few 
selected infrastructure projects (financed locally and by multilateral development 
partners) recently implemented in the country.  
(iv)  Consult  with  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  and  other  development 
partners  to  identify  lessons  from  their  experience  with  LAR  planning  and 
implementation in the country. 
(v)  Draft the country assessment and capacity building plan; and discuss it with 
relevant DMC agencies, NGOs, and other development partners. 
(vi)  Review  country  reports  and  capacity  building  programs,  and  provide  it  for 
endorsement to the relevant agency. 
(vii)  Arrange  the  establishment  of  working  LAR,  including  a  land  administration 
agency, selected executing agencies and local governments, NGOs, and other 
development partners. 
 
9.  Output 2. Policy alignment and LAR administration enhancement (international: 
24.5 person-months; national: 54 person-months). In each participating DMC (except initially 
Turkmenistan), the activities for this output will start once the LAR working group is established 
and phase 1 is completed successfully. Activities include the following: 
 
(i)  Conduct meetings with the LAR working group every 2 months. 
(ii)  Identify changes of LAR practices that are possible without legal reform and 
changes requiring legal reform. 
(iii)  Develop  effective  coordination  mechanisms  connecting  the  various  agencies 
involved in LAR. 
(iv)  Draft new implementing rules and regulations and a LAR coordination plan in 
consultation with relevant agencies, NGOs, and other development partners. 
(v)  Facilitate the approval of the new implementing rules and regulations by the 
appropriate authority. 
(vi)  Draft an agenda and action plan for changes in LAR practice requiring legal 
reform. 
(vii)  Facilitate government approval of the LAR legal reform plan. 
(viii)  Establish  a  mechanism  for  documenting  and  reporting  complaints  to  be 
thoroughly discussed with governments and NGOs. 
(ix)  Prepare a report detailing the results of this output and including the documents 
agreed to by the government. 
(x)  Prepare  knowledge  materials  to  be  provided  to  executing  agencies,  local 
governments, and civil society organizations. 
 
10.  Output 3. Technical capacity building through on-the job training and TA results 
evaluation  (international  24.5  person-months;  national  216  person-months)  In  each 
participating DMC, TA activities for this output will start after the establishment of the LAR 
working group and include the following: 
 
(i)  Finalize  the  training  program  and  identify  training  participants  among  land 
acquisition agencies, executing agencies, NGOs, and national consultants. 
(ii)  Prepare training modules and materials.

Appendix 4  13
(iii)  A training program entailing at least 8 one-day classroom sessions and 1 field 
training. 
(iv)  Prepare a business plan and terms of reference for the establishment of a LAR 
unit in major executing agencies. 
(v)  Prepare  a  roster  of  capable  national  LAR  consultants  and  model  terms  of 
reference for executing agencies for their eventual engagement as consultants in 
project preparation and implementation. 
(vi)  Prepare a medium-term on-the-job coaching program for executing agencies. 
(vii)  Conduct the medium-term, on-the-job coaching program for executing agencies. 
The program will assist executing agencies in resolving routine problems in LAR 
preparation and implementation, and in implementing their LAR monitoring tasks. 
Continue  to  work  with  land  administration  agencies  to  advance  the  policy 
alignment agenda, and coordinate with LAR external monitoring agencies under 
ADB projects to prepare the final TA evaluation.  
(viii)  Carry out a final evaluation of the TA results.
